<ce:figure id="FIG1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Molecular geometry and atom labelling scheme of [Cu(pyza)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>I]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>. Symmetry codes are according to <ce:cross-ref refid="TBL3">Table 3</ce:cross-ref>. Hydrogen bonds are indicated as broken lines.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  Molecular geometry and atom labelling scheme of [Cu(pyza)2I] n . Symmetry codes are according to Table 3. Hydrogen bonds are indicated as broken lines.

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Copper(I) salts form with pyrazine carboxamide (pyza) complexes of the type Cu(pyza)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>X for X=Cl, Br, I, NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pyza)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>X<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> for X=Cl and Br, Cu(pyza)X for X=Cl, Br and I, and Cu(pyza)I·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. The complexes were characterized by elemental analysis and infrared, Raman and electron spectroscopy. The overall physical measurements suggest that pyza behaves as a monodentate ligand in all complexes, except the 1:1 bromide which contains <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-, and <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>O</ce:italic>-pyza molecules, whereas the halide, nitrate and perchlorate complexes behave as bridging ligands giving rise to polymeric structures. The structural determination of Cu(pyza)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>I reveals that the Cu and I atoms are arranged alternately to form a polymeric zigzag chain with an approximately tetrahedral copper(I) environment. These chains are connected via hydrogen bonds of the type N–H⋯O between two pyza molecules to form two-dimensional systems. The bromide and iodide complexes of all types display visible emission in the 640–675 nm region when irradiated in the UV, whereas the other complexes do not fluoresce at room temperature.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Copper(I) salts form with pyrazine carboxamide (pyza) complexes of the type Cu(pyza)2X for X=Cl, Br, I, NO3 and ClO4, Cu2(pyza)3X2 for X=Cl and Br, Cu(pyza)X for X=Cl, Br and I, and Cu(pyza)I⋅H2O. The complexes were characterized by elemental analysis and infrared, Raman and electron spectroscopy. The overall physical measurements suggest that pyza behaves as a monodentate ligand in all complexes, except the 1:1 bromide which contains N-, and N,O-pyza molecules, whereas the halide, nitrate and perchlorate complexes behave as bridging ligands giving rise to polymeric structures. The structural determination of Cu(pyza)2I reveals that the Cu and I atoms are arranged alternately to form a polymeric zigzag chain with an approximately tetrahedral copper(I) environment. These chains are connected via hydrogen bonds of the type N-H⋯O between two pyza molecules to form two-dimensional systems. The bromide and iodide complexes of all types display visible emission in the 640-675 nm region when irradiated in the UV, whereas the other complexes do not fluoresce at room temperature.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Hoskins and Robson  have proposed that infinite-ordered frameworks may be formed by linking together tetrahedral or octahedral metal centres through rod-like connecting ligands, such as pyrazine. These coordination polymers  present potential utility in host–guest chemistry, ion exchange and heterogeneous catalysis. Thus, numerous examples of pyrazine-bridged derivatives of copper(II) complexes have been prepared and structurally characterized in order to study the ability of the pyrazine bridge to mediate interactions in novel one-  and two-dimensional  materials. Pyrazine carboxamide (otherwise known as pyrazine amide <ce:bold>(I),</ce:bold> hereafter abbreviated as pyza), while keeping the rod-like nature of pyrazine, adds two coordination centres (namely –CO and –NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> groups), thereby increasing the coordination ability of pyza as a ligand. It has been pointed out  that pyza acts as a bidentate ligand with coordination via the O atom and N α-hetero atom of the ring in M(OAc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pyza)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (M=Mn or Ni), whereas it acts as a monodentate ligand with coordination through the N β-hetero atom and carbonyl O atom in the corresponding Cu and Hg complexes, respectively. Complexes of pyza with many transition metal ions, including Ni(II), Co(II) , Fe(II), Cu(II), Zn(II), Cd(II), Hg(II) and Pd(II) , as well as with Ti(IV) and Zr(IV) , have been studied. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility studies of CuX<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pyza)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> suggested a one-dimensional chain structure for these complexes . Crystal structures have been determined for ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pyza)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
 and Cu(pyza)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
. The zinc centre is tetrahedrally coordinated in ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pyza)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, whereas the copper centre, which is chelated by the amide O atom and α-N atom of two ligand molecules, is weakly bonded to other N atoms of the pyrazine rings of two neighbouring complex molecules in Cu(pyza)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
. To the best of our knowledge no copper(I) complex of pyza has been reported in the literature. In the present paper we report the synthesis and characterization of such copper(I) complexes, together with the X-ray structure determination of the title iodide complex, the first to have been reported.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Hoskins and Robson  have proposed that infinite-ordered frameworks may be formed by linking together tetrahedral or octahedral metal centres through rod-like connecting ligands, such as pyrazine. These coordination polymers  present potential utility in host-guest chemistry, ion exchange and heterogeneous catalysis. Thus, numerous examples of pyrazine-bridged derivatives of copper(II) complexes have been prepared and structurally characterized in order to study the ability of the pyrazine bridge to mediate interactions in novel one-  and two-dimensional  materials. Pyrazine carboxamide (otherwise known as pyrazine amide (I), hereafter abbreviated as pyza), while keeping the rod-like nature of pyrazine, adds two coordination centres (namely -CO and -NH2 groups), thereby increasing the coordination ability of pyza as a ligand. It has been pointed out  that pyza acts as a bidentate ligand with coordination via the O atom and N α-hetero atom of the ring in M(OAc)2(pyza)2 (M=Mn or Ni), whereas it acts as a monodentate ligand with coordination through the N β-hetero atom and carbonyl O atom in the corresponding Cu and Hg complexes, respectively. Complexes of pyza with many transition metal ions, including Ni(II), Co(II) , Fe(II), Cu(II), Zn(II), Cd(II), Hg(II) and Pd(II) , as well as with Ti(IV) and Zr(IV) , have been studied. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility studies of CuX2(pyza)2 suggested a one-dimensional chain structure for these complexes . Crystal structures have been determined for ZnCl2(pyza)2  and Cu(pyza)2(ClO4)2 . The zinc centre is tetrahedrally coordinated in ZnCl2(pyza)2, whereas the copper centre, which is chelated by the amide O atom and α-N atom of two ligand molecules, is weakly bonded to other N atoms of the pyrazine rings of two neighbouring complex molecules in Cu(pyza)2(ClO4)2 . To the best of our knowledge no copper(I) complex of pyza has been reported in the literature. In the present paper we report the synthesis and characterization of such copper(I) complexes, together with the X-ray structure determination of the title iodide complex, the first to have been reported.

<ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Pyrazine carboxamide (pyza) was purchased from Aldrich; other chemicals are of analytical grade quality.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Preparation of complexes</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Cu(pyza)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>X (X=Cl, Br, I)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">
<ce:small-caps>l-</ce:small-caps>(+)-Ascorbic acid was added to an aqueous solution mixture of Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.48 g, 2 mmol) and NaX (in 1:1 molar ratio with respect to copper). A saturated solution of NaX was then added dropwise until a clear solution was obtained. Upon addition of an ethanol solution of pyza (0.83 g, 6 mmol) and boiling, a clear yellow solution was produced. The final mixture was allowed to stand for several days to yield red crystals of the complexes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Pyrazine carboxamide (pyza) was purchased from Aldrich; other chemicals are of analytical grade quality.

Preparation of complexes

Cu(pyza)2X (X=Cl, Br, I)

 l-(+)-Ascorbic acid was added to an aqueous solution mixture of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.48 g, 2 mmol) and NaX (in 1:1 molar ratio with respect to copper). A saturated solution of NaX was then added dropwise until a clear solution was obtained. Upon addition of an ethanol solution of pyza (0.83 g, 6 mmol) and boiling, a clear yellow solution was produced. The final mixture was allowed to stand for several days to yield red crystals of the complexes.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pyza)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>X<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (X=Cl, Br)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">These complexes were prepared according to the above method except that the amount of pyza added was in a molar ratio of 2:1 to copper.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Cu(pyza)I·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">This complex was prepared as above except that the molar ratio of pyza to copper was 1:1. The final mixture was allowed to stand in the open air for several days to yield the complex.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Cu(pyza)X (X=Cl, Br, I)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">These complexes were prepared by mixing a suspension of CuX (2 mmol) in water with a boiled aqueous solution of pyza (0.27 g, 2 mmol). The complexes were deposited as powder samples after several minutes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Cu2(pyza)3X2 (X=Cl, Br)

These complexes were prepared according to the above method except that the amount of pyza added was in a molar ratio of 2:1 to copper.

Cu(pyza)I⋅H2O

This complex was prepared as above except that the molar ratio of pyza to copper was 1:1. The final mixture was allowed to stand in the open air for several days to yield the complex.

Cu(pyza)X (X=Cl, Br, I)

These complexes were prepared by mixing a suspension of CuX (2 mmol) in water with a boiled aqueous solution of pyza (0.27 g, 2 mmol). The complexes were deposited as powder samples after several minutes.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Cu(pyza)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>X (X=NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> or ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">These complexes were prepared by the addition of <ce:small-caps>l-</ce:small-caps>(+)-ascorbic acid to a mixture of Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O or Cu(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and pyza in a molar ratio of 1:2.5, in aqueous ethanol medium. The final mixture was boiled, cooled and allowed to stand for several hours.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Cu(pyza)2X (X=NO3 or ClO4)

These complexes were prepared by the addition of l-(+)-ascorbic acid to a mixture of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O or Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O and pyza in a molar ratio of 1:2.5, in aqueous ethanol medium. The final mixture was boiled, cooled and allowed to stand for several hours.

Elemental analysis

Elemental analysis results and some physical properties of the isolated complexes are listed in  .

Spectral measurements

The IR and Raman spectral data for some complexes are given in  . The experimental procedures and instruments used for different physical measurements are as described previously .

X-ray structural analyses

[Cu(pyza)2I] n , C10H10IN6O2, fw=436.68, monoclinic, space group P21/m (no. 11), a=4.1192(13), b=26.493(7), c=6.177(2) Å, β=97.16(2)°, V=668.9(3) Å3, Z=2; d c=2.168 Mg m-3. The X-ray single crystal data were collected on a modified STOE four circle diffractometer. Crystal size: 0.11×0.08×0.05 mm. Graphite-monochromatized MoKα radiation (λ=0.71069 Å) with the ω-scan technique was used to collect the data set. The accurate unit-cell parameters were determined from automatic centering of 47 reflections (3.7°<θ<15.6°) and refined by least-squares methods; 2040 reflections (1480 independent reflections, R int=0.0306) were collected in the range 3.08°<θ<26.97°. Corrections were applied for Lorentz polarization effects, and for absorption using the DIFABS  computer program (range of normalized transmission coefficients 0.340-1.000). The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 (i.e. squared), using the SHELXTL/PC V 5.03  program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were assigned isotropic displacement factors and included in the final refinements cycles by use of geometrical restraints. The final R indices are 0.0454 (R 1) and 0.1083 (wR 2) [I>2σ(I)]. Goodness-of-fit on F 2 is 1.193. Number of refined parameters is 102. Maximum and minimum peaks in the final difference Fourier synthesis were 1.253 [in vicinity of I(1)] and -1.288 e Å-3. Selected bond parameters are given in  .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The reactions between pyza and copper(I) halide, nitrate and perchlorate or the reduction of copper(II)–pyrazine carboxamide complex in the presence of these anions afforded the complexes given in . All the complexes are coloured and stable against air oxidation when well-dried. The copper(I) halide, nitrate and perchlorate complexes are insoluble in many non-polar solvents (e.g. benzene, carbontetrachloride, toluene) and polar solvents (e.g. water, alcohols, acetone), which is an indication of their polymeric nature.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

The reactions between pyza and copper(I) halide, nitrate and perchlorate or the reduction of copper(II)-pyrazine carboxamide complex in the presence of these anions afforded the complexes given in . All the complexes are coloured and stable against air oxidation when well-dried. The copper(I) halide, nitrate and perchlorate complexes are insoluble in many non-polar solvents (e.g. benzene, carbontetrachloride, toluene) and polar solvents (e.g. water, alcohols, acetone), which is an indication of their polymeric nature.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>IR and Raman spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The IR and Raman (R) spectral results for pyrazine carboxamide and some of its copper(I) complexes are given in . The assignments given are in accordance with those reported previously  for the parent ligand. The spectra of these complexes show a very strong band around 1700 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (IR) and 1670 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (R), suggesting that the carbonyl group does not participate in the coordination bond with copper(I). In case of the yellow 1:1 bromide complex two bands are observed at 1706 and 1662 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (IR), suggesting the existence of two types of pyza molecules; in one of them the carbonyl group coordinates the metal atom whereas it does not in the other. The small shift of the carbonyl band from 1714 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in the spectrum of free ligand may be due to hydrogen bonding. The bands due to the amino group in the 3400–2800 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> region and around 1610 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> are little influenced by coordination, and this again may be due to N–H⋯O hydrogen bonding. The spectrum of complex <ce:bold>8</ce:bold> shows a broad band of medium to strong intensity around 3450 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> due to the hydrogen-bonded water molecule. A broad band of medium intensity appears in the IR spectra of all complexes, except in the region 800–815 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for complex <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> and at 805 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in free pyza, which exists as dimers formed by hydrogen bonds between carboxamide groups. This band is assigned to the OH out-of-plane deformation of the system, similar to that reported for dimers formed by hydrogen bonds between carboxylic groups . In the 1600–400 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> region (pyrazine nucleus vibrations) the bands at 1581, 1054, 787 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (IR) and at 1576, 1051, 867, 805, 616 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (R) are slightly shifted; those at 619, 432 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (IR) and at 412 and 379 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (R) experience substantial shifts to higher frequencies, whereas the other bands are not affected or are slightly shifted to lower wave numbers upon complexation. Similar results have been reported for other metal complexes of pyrazine . These results suggest that pyza may act as a <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-monodentate ligand in all but one of the isolated copper(I) complexes. In the yellow 1:1 bromide complex one pyza acts as a <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-monodentate whereas the other acts as a <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>O</ce:italic>-bidentate ligand. Further evidence for the presence of two different pyza molecules in the above complex comes from the splitting and appearance of a large number of peaks (). In the far IR region we could not locate any absorption band due to <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>Cu–Cl or Cu–Br above 200 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, the region where these vibrations are expected . This suggests that the halide atoms act as bridging ligand in these complexes. The spectra of the 1:2 copper(I) perchlorate complex show three peaks at 1144, 1112 and 1087 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and two peaks at 636 and 628 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (IR), and at 1096, 1068 and 1037 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and at 673, 658 and 620 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (R), due to <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> modes of the perchlorate, a result which indicates a bridging bidentate perchlorate group . Likewise the appearance of strong bands at 1313 and 1436 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> due to <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> and <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> (IR), respectively, of the NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> group is suggestive of a bridging bidentate nitrate group in the respective complex. The above conclusions are confirmed by crystal structure determination of the 1:2 copper(I), bromide (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and iodide (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) complexes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
IR and Raman spectra

The IR and Raman (R) spectral results for pyrazine carboxamide and some of its copper(I) complexes are given in . The assignments given are in accordance with those reported previously  for the parent ligand. The spectra of these complexes show a very strong band around 1700 cm-1 (IR) and 1670 cm-1 (R), suggesting that the carbonyl group does not participate in the coordination bond with copper(I). In case of the yellow 1:1 bromide complex two bands are observed at 1706 and 1662 cm-1 (IR), suggesting the existence of two types of pyza molecules; in one of them the carbonyl group coordinates the metal atom whereas it does not in the other. The small shift of the carbonyl band from 1714 cm-1 in the spectrum of free ligand may be due to hydrogen bonding. The bands due to the amino group in the 3400-2800 cm-1 region and around 1610 cm-1 are little influenced by coordination, and this again may be due to N-H⋯O hydrogen bonding. The spectrum of complex 8 shows a broad band of medium to strong intensity around 3450 cm-1 due to the hydrogen-bonded water molecule. A broad band of medium intensity appears in the IR spectra of all complexes, except in the region 800-815 cm-1 for complex 7 and at 805 cm-1 in free pyza, which exists as dimers formed by hydrogen bonds between carboxamide groups. This band is assigned to the OH out-of-plane deformation of the system, similar to that reported for dimers formed by hydrogen bonds between carboxylic groups . In the 1600-400 cm-1 region (pyrazine nucleus vibrations) the bands at 1581, 1054, 787 cm-1 (IR) and at 1576, 1051, 867, 805, 616 cm-1 (R) are slightly shifted; those at 619, 432 cm-1 (IR) and at 412 and 379 cm-1 (R) experience substantial shifts to higher frequencies, whereas the other bands are not affected or are slightly shifted to lower wave numbers upon complexation. Similar results have been reported for other metal complexes of pyrazine . These results suggest that pyza may act as a N-monodentate ligand in all but one of the isolated copper(I) complexes. In the yellow 1:1 bromide complex one pyza acts as a N-monodentate whereas the other acts as a N,O-bidentate ligand. Further evidence for the presence of two different pyza molecules in the above complex comes from the splitting and appearance of a large number of peaks (). In the far IR region we could not locate any absorption band due to νCu-Cl or Cu-Br above 200 cm-1, the region where these vibrations are expected . This suggests that the halide atoms act as bridging ligand in these complexes. The spectra of the 1:2 copper(I) perchlorate complex show three peaks at 1144, 1112 and 1087 cm-1 and two peaks at 636 and 628 cm-1 (IR), and at 1096, 1068 and 1037 cm-1 and at 673, 658 and 620 cm-1 (R), due to ν 3 and ν 1 modes of the perchlorate, a result which indicates a bridging bidentate perchlorate group . Likewise the appearance of strong bands at 1313 and 1436 cm-1 due to ν 5 and ν 1 (IR), respectively, of the NO3 - group is suggestive of a bridging bidentate nitrate group in the respective complex. The above conclusions are confirmed by crystal structure determination of the 1:2 copper(I), bromide (3) and iodide (4) complexes.

The copper and iodide ions are arranged alternately to form a polymeric zigzag chain [I–Cu–I=99.49(5)°, Cu–I–Cu=99.49(5)°] extending along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis. The almost planar hydrogen-bonded pyza dimeric unit [mean deviation from planarity=0.034 Å; torsion angle C(5D)–O(1D)⋯N(3)–C(5)=−2.7°] is diagonally linked, through the nitrogen atoms, N(1), to two metal centres belonging to adjacent (CuI)<ce:inf loc="post">

elements.clean_text:
Structure of [Cu(pyza)2I] n  

The structural determination of [Cu(pyza)2I] n  confirms the presence of pyza dimers as inferred by the IR spectral results given above. Cu+ and I- occupy special positions on mirror planes with multiplicity 2; thus the asymmetric unit ( ) corresponds exactly to 2:1 pyza-CuI stoichiometry. The copper and iodide ions are arranged alternately to form a polymeric zigzag chain [I-Cu-I=99.49(5)°, Cu-I-Cu=99.49(5)°] extending along the a-axis. The almost planar hydrogen-bonded pyza dimeric unit [mean deviation from planarity=0.034 Å; torsion angle C(5D)-O(1D)⋯N(3)-C(5)=-2.7°] is diagonally linked, through the nitrogen atoms, N(1), to two metal centres belonging to adjacent (CuI) n  chains ( ). The coordination geometry about the copper(I) atom is thus approximately tetrahedral (), and the resulting crystal structure comprises layers parallel to the ab set of planes.

<ce:para view="all">The present structure is very similar to that of the previously reported CuCl(HNA)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> complex (HNA is nicotinic acid) , having tetrahedral copper(I) atoms and zigzag (CuCl)<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> chains. While the measured Cu–N bond distances () lie within the range of 2.00–2.05 Å for copper(I) complexes with pyridine and substituted pyridine ligands , the Cu–I bonds are longer than those found [2.475(4), 2.611(4) Å] in the structure of [Cu(s-collidine)I]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> containing trigonal planar copper(I) . Complexes of stoichiometry L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CuX, where L=pyridine or substituted pyridine and X=halogen, commonly exist as bis(μ-halo)-bridged [L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CuX]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> dimers with a cyclic Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>X<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> core . When steric crowding of the ligand prevents dimerization, a mononuclear, pseudo-trigonal planar L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CuX complexes are produced, as found in the structures of (2,6-Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>py)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·CuX, X=Cl, Br  or I . The present structure is an example of the rare polymeric structure of L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CuX stoichiometry, the existence of which may be ascribed to the stabilizing influence of the hydrogen-bonded pyrazine carboxamide.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The present structure is very similar to that of the previously reported CuCl(HNA)2 complex (HNA is nicotinic acid) , having tetrahedral copper(I) atoms and zigzag (CuCl) n  chains. While the measured Cu-N bond distances () lie within the range of 2.00-2.05 Å for copper(I) complexes with pyridine and substituted pyridine ligands , the Cu-I bonds are longer than those found [2.475(4), 2.611(4) Å] in the structure of [Cu(s-collidine)I] n  containing trigonal planar copper(I) . Complexes of stoichiometry L2CuX, where L=pyridine or substituted pyridine and X=halogen, commonly exist as bis(μ-halo)-bridged [L2CuX]2 dimers with a cyclic Cu2X2 core . When steric crowding of the ligand prevents dimerization, a mononuclear, pseudo-trigonal planar L2CuX complexes are produced, as found in the structures of (2,6-Me2py)2⋅CuX, X=Cl, Br  or I . The present structure is an example of the rare polymeric structure of L2CuX stoichiometry, the existence of which may be ascribed to the stabilizing influence of the hydrogen-bonded pyrazine carboxamide.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Electronic spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The electronic spectra (
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL4"></ce:float-anchor>, 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG3"></ce:float-anchor>) of the solid copper(I) complexes mulled in Nujol exhibit strong absorption bands in the visible region, which are due to metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) from Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> to an empty π<ce:sup loc="post">*</ce:sup> orbital on the pyza molecule. The brown to black complexes (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>10</ce:bold>), however, show two such MLCT bands. A similar situation occurs in the copper(I)–pyrazinic acid complexes , in the bis(arylazo-oximates) of copper(I)  and in bis[(2-phenylazo)-pyridine]copper(I) complexes , except that the two bands appear at 700–780 nm and 550–580 nm, in the latter two cases, respectively. In a tetrahedral molecular environment, the metal valence d orbitals split into two sublevels, t<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and e. If the two MLCT bands observed in the spectra of some of the present complexes are due to t<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–π<ce:sup loc="post">*</ce:sup> (516–618 nm) and e–π<ce:sup loc="post">*</ce:sup> (400–428 nm), the energy gap between them lies in the range 7100–6500 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. This difference is comparable to that observed for the above pyrazinic acid complexes, but much greater than that for arylazo-oximate or phenylazopyridine–copper(I) complexes. Copper(I) complexes of bipyridine and related ligands exhibit the lowest energy charge-transfer band near 450 nm , whereas those of pyridine and related ligands show an MLCT band around 300–500 nm . In grossly planar and unsaturated macrocyclic environments for copper(I), an allowed transition is documented  near 700 nm.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Electronic spectra

The electronic spectra ( ,  ) of the solid copper(I) complexes mulled in Nujol exhibit strong absorption bands in the visible region, which are due to metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) from CuI d10 to an empty π* orbital on the pyza molecule. The brown to black complexes (2-6, 10), however, show two such MLCT bands. A similar situation occurs in the copper(I)-pyrazinic acid complexes , in the bis(arylazo-oximates) of copper(I)  and in bis[(2-phenylazo)-pyridine]copper(I) complexes , except that the two bands appear at 700-780 nm and 550-580 nm, in the latter two cases, respectively. In a tetrahedral molecular environment, the metal valence d orbitals split into two sublevels, t2 and e. If the two MLCT bands observed in the spectra of some of the present complexes are due to t2-π* (516-618 nm) and e-π* (400-428 nm), the energy gap between them lies in the range 7100-6500 cm-1. This difference is comparable to that observed for the above pyrazinic acid complexes, but much greater than that for arylazo-oximate or phenylazopyridine-copper(I) complexes. Copper(I) complexes of bipyridine and related ligands exhibit the lowest energy charge-transfer band near 450 nm , whereas those of pyridine and related ligands show an MLCT band around 300-500 nm . In grossly planar and unsaturated macrocyclic environments for copper(I), an allowed transition is documented  near 700 nm.

<ce:section-title>Emission spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The results of the room temperature emission spectra of the solid copper(I) complexes are given in . The bromide and iodide complexes display emission spectra at room temperature with <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf> in the range 640–675 nm, whereas the chlorides of all types, the nitrate and the perchlorate complexes do not emit. The spectrum of each of the emitting compounds consists of a single slightly asymmetric band, as seen in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG4"></ce:float-anchor>. The luminescence spectra of all of the emitting compounds proved to be independent of the excitation wavelength, and their excitation spectra are very similar.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Emission spectra

The results of the room temperature emission spectra of the solid copper(I) complexes are given in . The bromide and iodide complexes display emission spectra at room temperature with λ max in the range 640-675 nm, whereas the chlorides of all types, the nitrate and the perchlorate complexes do not emit. The spectrum of each of the emitting compounds consists of a single slightly asymmetric band, as seen in  . The luminescence spectra of all of the emitting compounds proved to be independent of the excitation wavelength, and their excitation spectra are very similar.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The emission spectra of copper(I) halide complexes of pyridine and pyridine derivatives have been extensively studied  and found to display high-energy (HE; 430–540 nm) and low-energy (LE; 620–698 nm) bands. The HE band was attributed to MLCT or halide-to-metal charge transfer (XMCT) , and the LE band to the metal centre in the Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>X<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> core with Cu⋯Cu distances less than 2.8 Å . It is clear from  that the <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf> changes from 671 for the 1:2 bromide to 660 nm for the corresponding iodide, a result that is consistent with what has been observed previously , namely that the emission bands for the chloride clusters occur at lower energy than the HE bands of the respective iodide clusters. As these complexes do not possess the Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>X<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> core structure, the LE bands are not expected, and therefore the emitting state in the present copper(I) halide complexes of pyza would be triplet MLCT or XLCT excited states. The results given in  suggest that the emission spectra of the complexes of pyza experience a substantial shift to lower energies when compared with corresponding complexes of pyridine , which reflects the influence of the substituent in the skeleton of the aromatic ring itself.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The emission spectra of copper(I) halide complexes of pyridine and pyridine derivatives have been extensively studied  and found to display high-energy (HE; 430-540 nm) and low-energy (LE; 620-698 nm) bands. The HE band was attributed to MLCT or halide-to-metal charge transfer (XMCT) , and the LE band to the metal centre in the Cu4X4 core with Cu⋯Cu distances less than 2.8 Å . It is clear from  that the λ max changes from 671 for the 1:2 bromide to 660 nm for the corresponding iodide, a result that is consistent with what has been observed previously , namely that the emission bands for the chloride clusters occur at lower energy than the HE bands of the respective iodide clusters. As these complexes do not possess the Cu4X4 core structure, the LE bands are not expected, and therefore the emitting state in the present copper(I) halide complexes of pyza would be triplet MLCT or XLCT excited states. The results given in  suggest that the emission spectra of the complexes of pyza experience a substantial shift to lower energies when compared with corresponding complexes of pyridine , which reflects the influence of the substituent in the skeleton of the aromatic ring itself.
